comments.commentBody: The problem with Nate Silver's article is that fails to clarify that Rubio's "best" in "well-educated areas" may be behind Trump's not "far ahead" in the said areas.

replies.commentBody:
ESPN's 538 site had an article about how polling in Nevada was notoriously poor, largely because so many of the state's working folks are a) somewhat transient, and b) at the office/casino/restaurant kitchen during second shift, and pollsters generally call in the evenings. They're trying to call more often in the daytime, however, which I would not exactly favor if I were trying to catch a few hours' sleep before work.
http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/why-nevada-polls-are-bad/

comments.commentBody:
"If the polls are right...."

In Nevada the polls weren't right about Bernie Sanders, but in SC it is right about Trump? I guess it is all about the spin.

Harry Reid used his influence in Nevada to give the edge to Mrs. Clinton. The polls may have been right about Sanders winning the Hispanic vote, but in a caucus, external factors, such as Reid's influence, matter.

replies.commentBody: Watching Donald destroy the sad remains of the GOP is what makes this so much fun.

comments.commentBody:
We can see the field narrowing and the way the winds are blowing ... and it sure looks like Hillary vs The Donald.

There's a Texas-ism that describes what it is going to be: "uglier than the hind end of sick dog."

Trump is peddling a neo-fascist message at the moment, playing El Lider Boca Grande. The question is what does he do as he transitions to being the candidate? Republicans always run crazy-right to get the nomination and then try to do the Romney shuffle ... and it hasn't worked. That shuffle always includes trying to hold onto your angry base with dog-whistle, while trying to seem rational and more middle-of-the-road. It just made Romney look like a weasel, the danger of the strategy.

If you listened closely you can hear Trump cleaning up his message a bit -- but Trump doesn't do subtle, and isn't likely to want to follow Romney's losing path.

There will be blood. The first loser is the Republican party -- it can never recover into any older form. Buckley's conservatism is dead. Ronnie's conservatism is dead. Even Scalia's conservatism is dead.

The Republican "big-tent" is torn down: fascism, right-wing evangelicalism, and entreprenurial WASPism cannot pull together anymore.

replies.commentBody: What neither of you seems to understand is the United States was not founded as a Democracy. It was founded as a Republic. The apportionment of representation was carefully crafted by our rather wise founding fathers to avoid a pure democracy where demagogues could easily rule. They wisely mistrusted "the mob" with the vote. They also carefully divided representation between  representation of the populace in the House of Representatives and representation of the States in the Senate. The even took it a step further in the Presidential contests where the vote was further "buffered" by an Electoral College to which we elect delegates by State who are the only ones who can actually vote for a Presidential candidate. It may be messy, but it was a stroke of brilliance. All this was intended to keep the heat of the moment from sweeping away a carefully crafted representative Republic. I take it neither of you have taken an American Government class or, if you did, you didn't listen in class. True Democracies are truly dangerous and unstable. We expect a bit more from our government, but a little revolution like what you see in the successes of Trump and Sanders every once in a while clears the air. The idea is you don't get what you want; I don't get what I want; but, we both get what we really need.

C Ingram: The problem with that theory is your last sentence, which requires two sides who are each willing to accommodate the others' position to a degree. Today we have Ted Cruz as representative of a large portion of the Republican Party for whom "compromise" is the ultimate political evil. People like Ronald Reagan were able to work across the aisle to a large extent, by today's standards. It's ironic that today's "conservatives" continually cite Reagan while following essentially none of his politics.

Athenian Democracy crashed and burned within a few hundred years of its establishment sometime around the 5th century B.C. due to the rise of incompetent demagogues who pandered and flattered the citizens of Athens until Phillip and Alexander broke their collective backs at the Battle of Chaeronea in 338 B.C. The inherently fragile nature of democracy was much commented upon by Alexander's tutor Aristotle, who witnessed the nonsense first hand. The Founders wisely chose not to replicate a failed model but to blend it with aspects of the Roman Republic and existing British customs.

comments.commentBody: It makes absolutely no sense that both primaries and the overall election are not determined by the popular vote. Or that North Dakota gets as many senators as California or Texas. As a foreigner who has lived here for over a decade, I am still dumbfounded that voters in the populous, not-swing-states are not up in arms about this. It's a complete violation of the basic democratic principle that everyone's vote should carry equal weight.

comments.commentBody: Beware Washington Beltway, your time at the top of the moneyed/power pyramid is OVER! The same can be said for all the crooked lobbyists and their lamestream media supporters. In desperation they may create unspoken acts of terror in the United States to stop the imminent election of Donald Trump as President. The American way of life, what is left of it, is at stake, this is no joke. Vigilance and the support of each American who values their way of life and the future of America is crucial in the election of the only man not owned and truly loves his country, Donald Trump, 45th President of the United States of America!

Good points made in Comments about pundits and analysts perpetuating group think of the party establishments. Nate's been in the middle of the herd until recently when he (and a few others) discovered the GOP delegate allocation rules and stopped playing with his models.

That Trump and Cruz have the inside track to the nomination has been clear since November when the GOP issued its final primary and caucus rules. But it took conventional wisdom three months to realize that the rules didn't favor the establishment candidates as the party intended. See http://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2016/01/the-republican-estab...

Now, the media narrative and conventional wisdom is shifting: Trump has the inside track and could win the nomination with as little as 35 to 40% of the primary vote. This is especially significant since, according to CW, Trump's support is "capped" at around 35%--another myth.

But, when the votes are counted tonight, the course of the campaign might have slipped the grasp of CW again. Rubio is set to eliminate both Bush and Kasich, which would leave a single establishment candidate facing two or possibly three outsiders, if Carson remains. Rubio could then consolidate the party vote while Trump, Cruz and Carson fracture the anti-establishment, populist vote, creating an entirely new calculus for the pundits to ponder.

replies.commentBody: Give me Eisenhower - a radical liberal by today's standard.

comments.commentBody:
America needs really good leaders, but what we ELECT are just the really good campaigners. The chances of any of the popular top candidates actually being - or BECOMING - the best leaders probably runs one in ten.

Truman and Reagan were really fine Presidents but would Truman have made it into the White House without succeeding a dying FDR?

All the men elected since Reagan have been good campaigners without both the core values AND the merest preparation for serving as President. Some had the right values and some had been governors before, but nobody has had both.

The way thins are going, no one else ever will have everything we need or want, but Trump, Cruz, or Rubio can win and will definitely try had to repair the needless damage they will find facing them.

It's all high comedy, to me.
Sean Hannity gets more straight answers out of Trump that anyone else seems to.

replies.commentBody:
Both Nates have been aware of this for a long time, because it is obvious. What has not been obvious is that the number of Establishment candidates would be so high at this point of the primaries.

The irony here is that the problem for the Republicans appears to be caused by Citizens United - marginal candidates have so much money available to them in various ways that they aren't dropping out as fast as they normally would.

comments.commentBody: Sam Wang of the Princeton Election Consortium pointed this out a long time ago. Both Nate Silver (who seems to have a private grudge against Wang since 2014) and Nate Cohn (just unaware of Wang?) do not cite Wang's prior (and more comprehensive) delegate-based Republican primary analysis.

replies.commentBody:
That would require 3 things:
1) The "establishment" (aka billionaires other than Trump) all get together and decide to cut Bush and Rubio loose and drop a ton of money on Kasich.
OR: Bush and Rubio quit in spite of that not happening AND millions of "small" donors each send hundreds of dollars to Kasich.
2) Millions of folks now joyful at the prospect of a Trump OR Cruz OR Rubio victory fail to get off the couch come primary day.
3) Millions of non-billionaire "establishment" 'Pubs get inspired at the last minute and jump off their couches to run down and vote for Kasich.
All 3 of those would have to happen, and only #2 has even the slimmest ghost of a chance. Sorry, NGH.
We can only hope that a majority of voters in enough states recoil at the prospect of a big solid gold "Trump" sign on the White House and get off the couch in November to vote against him (AND Bloomberg doesn't split the anti-Trump vote and wind up giving him a plurality in enough states to take the Electoral College).
I presume you are a somewhat moderate Republican, and I also presume that Bernie or Hillary can count on your vote in November. Remember: unlike me, you live in a purple state, so your vote is crucial. Among others, the 15M residents of Seoul are counting on you once again.
I couldn't agree with you more, he's the most reasonable (and most qualified) candidates the Republicans can choose from, yet he's consistently spoken of as an also-ran.
Because Kasich is a joke with very little spport?

comments.commentBody: Why the New York Times resolutely fails to take the Kasich candidacy seriously is baffling.  He may be the darkest of darkest horses in South Carolina but if he manages even a fourth place finish, that could encourage him to persevere and attract more backers.

It is clear that he doesn't really want to be president, and he is not going to be nominated.
That is all.
The very reason why we have to abandon the delegate/electoral college practice.  The popular vote is All that matters.  We can get that with direct elections.

Ah, yes, winner-take-all. In all but two states, Maine and Nebraska, the same holds for the national election, too. It is theoretically possible win the majority of Electoral College votes by the margin of a single vote per state in a handful of states while losing in a landslide in the remainder, coming in with a loss in the popular vote by a margin of many millions. The opposite is also true: one could win 270 votes by taking enough of the lower population states by a single vote against huge losses in the heavily populated ones.

It would be most interesting, Nate, if you ran a few of those possibilities for us in a future column.

replies.commentBody: Seems to me like bridges are burned with respect to staffers not voters

comments.commentBody:
Great writing again, Nate. It describes how reality works, or can work. It's a little like watching sausage being made. And it serves as a warning to us that the bizarre has a significant probability of happening.

But maybe a Trump nomination, or, as you talk about here, accrual of majority delegates, isn't so bizarre after all. A large number of people will have voted for him in a democratic process, the outcome of which gives him those delegates. We're not a monarchy or dictatorship with succession rules that mandate Jeb and Hillary. Hillary still has to go through those primaries too.

I have a feeling that South Carolina could be a five way split as voters readjust their feelings given the recent news. Cruz down a bit, Rubio up, Carson gets some more of Cruz's evangelicals and Jeb or Kasich makes a showing simply because of his presence in the state. Trump drops a bit as a small number of his votes are apportioned among the other four candidates. If Kasich continues his momentum, it could be a six way split, his not having quite enough recognition to lead. Of course this could be wrong. It's fun to think about.

Should Jeb and Carson stumble, it will be another Bayesian measurement to update our probability distributions. I guess Carson's voters go to Cruz, but who knows how much Cruz has burned his bridges there? Jeb's could go to Rubio, but, uh, who knows how much he's burned his bridges there?

Keep providing us with your great analyses, Nate.

replies.commentBody: njglea--Paul Ryan is a Nightmare.  A leftover from the Republican contempt of the 47%.  He has even less capital that Mitt Romney.  And how will all those conservatives, who donated to this campaign or that one, feel about the party disregarding their wishes?  Will that finally make it clear that Republicans only need their votes and money, but don''t care what they think about anything.

The Donald is a deal maker and the money masters are interested in...Money! (Of course) So, why would one not assume these two parties could find an arrangement that satisfies both? The "real" candidate is the one that will deliver a victory in November.

If Trump wins in the first ballot, it's over.  Trump is the candidate.  If no one wins on the first ballot, anything can happen, and Ryan probably is a possible compromise candidate.  So far, though, Trump is looking like a pretty good bet.  Remember Jesse Ventura won the governorship in Minnesota with a protest candidacy that even he thought had no shot.
